description: From Middle English drosse, dros, from Old English drōs, an apocopated variant of Old English drōsna, drōsne (“a ground, sediment, lees, dregs, dirt, ear wax”), from *drēcg +‎ -sn, from Proto-Germanic *drōhsnǭ, from *dragjō +‎ *-snō, ("yeast, sediment"; compare *dragjō (“yeast”)), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰrā́ks (“sediment, yeast”).

Cognate with Scots dros, drose, drosse (“small particles, fragments, dross”), Middle Dutch droes (“dregs”), Dutch droesem (“dregs”), German Drusen (“lees, dregs”), Latin fracēs (“grounds or dregs of oil”). Related also to drast, dregs.

entries.meaning: Residue that forms on the surface of molten metal from oxidation.
A waste product from working with metal.

examples: What thou lovest well remains,  the rest is dross

verbs.description: dross (third-person singular simple present drosses, present participle drossing, simple past and past participle drossed)
